newsitem.title: FRANCE: Jospin says cannot suspend corporate layoffs.
newsitem.headline: Jospin says cannot suspend corporate layoffs.

text.p: French Socialist Prime Minister Lionel Jospin told his Communist coalition partners on Tuesday that the law did not allow authorities to suspend layoff programmes.
"We have to be clear the law does not permit ... suspension of layoff programmes," he said as he arrived at a weekly Socialist Party meeting. "We can't do something the law doesn't allow."

His statement followed calls by Communist leader Robert Hue for authorities to suspend job reduction programmes announced by companies this summer in the face of near record 12.5 percent unemployment.
But Jospin told reporters, "We certainly have to change the law," saying it would not be good to see job cut programmes multiply.

Jospin said the government would discuss the issue with unions and business heads to seek "something, perhaps, that respects the need for economic efficiency and at the same time defends salaried employees' rights".

At a meeting later in the day with Jospin, Communist party leaders said they had won a commitment from the prime minister that he would consider suspending public assistance for companies that went ahead with massive layoffs this summer.
The Communists were included in the leftist coalition government after the Socialists failed to win an absolute majority in last month's parliamentary election.
Hue urged Jospin on Monday to take immediate action to tackle unemployment rather than put off decisions on key jobs programmes until the autumn.
The Communists have been impatient with Jospin for failing to stop carmaker Renault from closing a Belgian plant, despite an election campaign promise to review the matter.
But Hue has said that the Communists have no intention of deserting the governing coalition.
